description.plain:
Megan Jovon Ruth Pete (b. February 15, 1995), best known by her stage name Megan Thee Stallion, and also known by her alter-ego names Tina Snow and Hot Girl Meg is a rapper from Houston, Texas.

Meg grew up the daughter of rapper Holly-Wood (Holly Thomas), and listened to Southern rap staples like Three 6 Mafia and UGK from an early age. By 14 years old, this had largely inspired her to start writing her own raps, and she then went on to establish her presence around the Houston rap circuit by battling and beating opponents in local freestyle competitions.

In the present: sexually explicit yet empowering lyrics combined with effortless flows have become Megan’s signature sound—as she strives to emulate her favorite parts of her male rapper influences (such as Pimp C and Biggie Smalls) but in a female version.

  


In November 2018, Meg signed with 300 Entertainment, making her the first female artist on the label. However, she would later end up suing 300 as a result of them blocking her from releasing music. After this, Roc Nation began managing Meg, which boosted her journey to mainstream superstardom that had already begun on the social media app TikTok with her song “Savage.”
The subsequent Beyoncé-assisted “Savage Remix” then helped Meg attain her first number one single on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in May 2020.

Unfortunately, two months on, Megan sustained gunshot wounds and had to undergo surgery to remove bullet fragments from her feet. She later alleged it was musician and acquaintance Tory Lanez that fired the gun—causing a messy, high-profile public controversy to transpire.
Not letting the incident hold her back, the career-defining hit “WAP” that Meg shared with fellow femcee Cardi B was released in August, also reaching number one and making history in the process.

Some months after, Megan’s debut album Good News dropped, addressing some of 2020’s drama and highlighting her growth as an artist from the four EP’s that came before it.

  


On March 14, 2021, at her first ever Grammy Awards ceremony—Megan won three categories. These were Best New Artist, Best Rap Song, and Best Rap Performance.
At the end of the same year, she released her first ever compilation album and graduated from Texas Southern University, earning a bachelor of science degree in health administration.

Then, in 2022, Megan used her 27th birthday to launch the Pete & Thomas Foundation—a non-profit organization named after her late parents and designed to give back to people in need.

songs.full_title: Cash Shit by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. DaBaby)
songs.title: Cash Shit

description.plain:
Released on Megan Thee Stallion’s debut mixtape Fever, the hit “Cash Shit” is the first of the numerous collaborations between Megan and Charlotte, North Carolina rapper Dababy.

Over a very simple beat provided by LilJuMadeDaBeat, the two artists elaborate on—as suggested by the title—their money: where they got it from and how they spend it.

songs.full_title: Savage by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Savage

description.plain:
Megan Thee Stallion decisively manifests herself as a “savage” on the second track from her third EP Suga, released on March 6, 2020. With plenty of references to her older songs and uplifting lyricism, it’s clear that Megan will indeed “forever be that bitch.”

Four days after Suga was released, choreographer Keara Wilson created an original dance to the track on TikTok, a popular video-sharing social media network. In the following days, the dance quickly became viral, even to the point of Megan shouting-out various TikTok creators putting their own spin to the dance.

The “Savage Remix” featuring Beyoncé was released on April 29, 2020 and an animated music video for the original version followed on May 21, 2020.

songs.full_title: Body by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Body

description.plain:
On “Body,” Megan Thee Stallion brags about her desirability, being the envy of other women, and the fantasy of their men.  It served as the fourth single to Good News, and dropped the night of the album’s release with a video. The track features a rapid-paced instrumental built around a sample of a woman moaning.

The music video that dropped with it featured cameos including Blac Chyna,  Taraji P. Henson, Jordyn Woods, Asian Da Brat, among others.

songs.full_title: Thot Shit by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Thot Shit

description.plain:
“Thot Shit” is Megan Thee Stallion’s first solo song of 2021 and brings about the highly-anticipated return of her alter-ego Tina Snow.

Much like her previous hits “Savage,” and “Body,” “Thot Shit” sees Megan flexing her success and confidence over an energetic, feel-good instrumental.

The droplet single got to #16 on the Billboard Hot 100 the week of its release, and would later appear on the tracklist of Megan’s October mixtape Something For Thee Hotties – a gift from her to her fans.

songs.artist_names: Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. Nicki Minaj & Ty Dolla $ign)
songs.full_title: Hot Girl Summer by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. Nicki Minaj & Ty Dolla $ign)
songs.title: Hot Girl Summer
songs.title_with_featured: Hot Girl Summer (Ft. Nicki Minaj & Ty Dolla $ign)

description.plain:
“Hot Girl Summer” is the highly-anticipated seasonal smash-hit by Houston rapper Megan Thee Stallion, who enlisted Ty Dolla $ign for the chorus, and the self-professed rap Queen, Nicki Minaj for a featured verse.

Megan first mentioned the song on July 18, 2019, via Twitter:

I feel like it’s only right I drop a hot girl summer song before the summer is over

Two days later, the rapper took to Instagram to tease a short snippet of one of her verses. Eight days after that, a longer snippet and official announcement followed, with Megan stating the track would be dropping on August 2, 2019.

On July 28, 2019, Megan had her first formal conversation with Nicki Minaj, via Instagram Live. Megan teased Nicki about her busy schedule stopping her from getting involved with the song, and hinted that if Nicki could free up her time, there would be a free space on the track.

Following this, on August 1, 2019, Megan took to Twitter to explain that the song’s release date would be delayed by seven days, but would also be “so worth the wait.” This lead to speculation that Nicki Minaj would appear on the track and needed extra time to add her verse.

On August 5, 2019, this theory was confirmed by Megan herself on Instagram:

THE HOT GIRLS TOOK OVER THE MF SUMMER SO IT WAS ONLY RIGHT TO GIVE THE HOTTIES THE OFFICIAL TRACK !!! HOT GIRL SUMMER FT. @nickiminaj and @tydollasign dropping 8/9 🔥🔥🔥🔥

Moments later, Nicki also promoted the song on Instagram. Both women shared the album artwork in their posts. An excerpt from Nicki’s caption reads:

Did I really do a verse for this song the night we got off that live?

The track’s music video released on September 3rd, 2019.

songs.full_title: Girls in the Hood by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Girls in the Hood

description.plain:
“Girls in the Hood” is the second single off of Megan’s debut album, Good News and was announced on social media two days before its release.

The song takes the shape of a steady trap beat that features her quintessential lyrics about haters, her lavish lifestyle and her approach to men. Similarly to “B.I.T.C.H” which came before it, Megan samples a hip-hop classic released by a male (in this case Eazy-E) and flips it to the girl version.

Upon the track’s existence being revealed to the public, Eazy-E’s daughters clashed over the sample. ReeMarkable voiced her frustration at not getting clearance to use her father’s music herself when other artists can, whilst Ebie Wright praised Megan for paying homage to her dad. Thee Stallion did not address any of this drama.

songs.title: Captain Hook

description.plain: “Captain Hook” is the third track off of Megan Thee Stallion’s third EP Suga. The song features Megan rapping against those who attempt to get in the way of her craft and also features lyrics surrounding sex. It was released as the second single from the project and was the second song to be given a music video.

songs.title: B.I.T.C.H.

description.plain:
“B.I.T.C.H” is the lead single by Houston rapper Megan Thee Stallion to her project Suga.

On January 9, 2020, Megan teased the song for the first time on Instagram with a video of her rapping to the song. Five days later, she confirmed in a tweet that she will be dropping the song on January 24, 2020.

songs.full_title: Big Ole Freak by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Big Ole Freak

description.plain:
“Big Ole Freak” is not just an anthem about being sexy, but also about being confident.

The single boosted an interest in the artist, establishing a more mainstream presence for her.
It is the most streamed track from EP Tina Snow.

About the song, in an interview with The Madd Hatta Morning Show, Megan said:

It’s about me being confident in my sexuality, and other women not being scared of being confident.

The track begins by sampling a classic R&B bop titled “Is It Love This Time?” but then picks up into a trap beat. Megan changes her flow a couple of times throughout, increasing speed and switching rhymes, while the sample consistently fades in and out in the background.

A music video for the song was released on 28 February 2019, with a behind the scenes follow-up succeeding two weeks later.

On 15 April, 2019, Big Ole Freak entered the Billboard Hot 100 chart, making it her first ever entry. Megan took to social media to celebrate with her fans. To her Instagram, she posted a screenshot of the official chartdata tweet with the caption:
«We made it on @billboard hot 100 hotties !!! Look I don’t have an album out yet , this is my first Entry EVER on the hot 100 chart , never got any handouts, I’m working my mf ass off everyday! I just wanna tell y’all I AINT NEVER FUCKIN STOPPING 🔥🔥🔥 I love my fuckin hotties keep streaming BOF !»

The track’s ominous instrumental is built around a crying sample and features a heavy-hitting beat.

songs.full_title: Freak Nasty by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Freak Nasty

description.plain:
“Freak Nasty” is a track from Houston rapper Megan Thee Stallion’s second extended play Tina Snow and pays homage to Tee Grizzley’s 2017 track “No Effort.”

The song is one of Megan’s favourite’s in her discography. When she visited Teen Vogue to create “The Playlist of Her Life,” she featured “Freak Nasty” as one of the songs and said:


 I really listen to this song a lot, because when i work out I really listen to it, the beat is just so uptempo. I was really in my bag that day, and i was really talking my shit. I remember being in the booth that day and I was really talking my shit, and I remember just being in the booth, and this is around the time when I had first signed to my label. My boy T Farris, he had never heard me really rap before, so he came in the room and I’m rapping and everybody in the room is like…

I knew they knew I could rap but they had never seen me rap in person, so it made me feel real good to see everybody in the room, especially a room full of men be like “Oh shit, oh she can really rap.”


Produced by frequent collaborator and hit-maker LilJiuMadeDaBeat, the uptempo track feature’s Megan’s classic writing and energy, and despite not being released as single, gained a music video a month after Tina Snow’s release.

songs.full_title: Don't Stop by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. Young Thug)
songs.title: Don’t Stop

description.plain:
“Don’t Stop” is Megan Thee Stallion’s first release since the summer smash-hit “WAP” that she shared with Cardi B. The song is the third single off of Megan’s debut album, Good News.

A bass-heavy beat with an electronic loop stays constant throughout, whilst Meg and trap genre pioneer Young Thug deliver braggadocious bars about their lavish lifestyles and unapologetic attitudes.

The collaboration was announced on social media three days prior to it dropping, with Megan going live on Youtube half an hour before the dual song and music video release.

songs.full_title: Shots Fired by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Shots Fired

description.plain:
On “Shots Fired,” the introduction to Megan’s debut album, she promptly and briefly addresses the July 2020 shooting incident that involved her and Tory Lanez–whom she refrains from naming on the song.

The song serves to end the conversation around the shooting so that the rest of the album is focused on what else Megan has to say. She also briefly calls into question the lack of justice for Breonna Taylor and other black women.

The track notably samples “I’m Afraid the Masquerade Is Over” by David Porter, which is the source used in The Notorious B.I.G.’s hit, “Who Shot Ya?”

songs.full_title: Plan B by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Plan B

description.plain:
Expected to act as the second single from Megan Thee Stallion’s upcoming second full-length album, “Plan B” is a candid female empowerment anthem in which Meg addresses a former lover that she feels disappointed by and shows that she knows her worth.

While oozing confidence and rapping classically over an old school ‘90s style beat, Megan delivers punchy lyrics that encourage women to be independent, love themselves, and be wary of men that may mistreat them.

  


On April 7, 2022, Megan took to Twitter to say that she was thinking of previewing an unheard song during her first ever Coachella performance that was scheduled for just over a week later. She explained:

Every time I play it for a woman they start jumping and clapping 😂

This idea came to fruition on April 16 and Meg debuted a snippet during her set, dedicating it to “whom it may the fuck concern,” and declaring that it is “very motherfucking personal” to her.

Clips of the unveilling went viral on social media—racking up millions of views in just a couple of days—and causing fans to beg the rapper to drop the full track immediately. Catering to this demand, on April 19, Megan obliged and announced that the official release date would be the following Friday.

songs.full_title: Realer by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Realer

description.plain:
Houston rapper Megan Thee Stallion proves she’s one of the hardest in the game with “Realer,” the introduction to her debut mixtape Fever, released in 2019.

The song features production from frequent collaborator LilJuMadeDaBeat, who also worked on Megan’s hits “Big Ole Freak” and “Cash Shit.” Ju is credited as a producer on 6 of the 14 tracks that appear on Fever.

“Realer” was released as the mixtapes second single a day before it’s release with it’s video premiering days later.

songs.title: Megan’s Piano

description.plain: On the monumental “Megan’s Piano,” rapper Megan Thee Stallion receives her first ever producer credit for playing the catchy piano riff that loops all the way through the song. A basic but booming backing track puts both the piano notes and Megan’s lyrics about her wealth and success front and center.

songs.full_title: Diamonds by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. Normani)
songs.title: Diamonds

description.plain:
The lead single off the Birds of Prey (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack), “Diamonds,” is a collaboration between American rapper Megan Thee Stallion and singer Normani. As the song title suggests, the song is about diamonds and it being “a girl’s best friend.”

On December 17, 2019, co-writer Kameron Glasper confirmed the existence of the collaboration via an Instagram story. A set of photos from the unreleased music video were posted on December 21st. Weeks later — on 8 January, 2020 — the single art was unveiled and the song was released later on January 10, 2020.

songs.full_title: Megan Monday Freestyle by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Megan Monday Freestyle

description.plain:
In her only freestyle of 2020, Megan flows effortlessly over a fast-paced buzzing beat courtesy of Lil Ju. Her usual punchy lyrics discuss her success, her critics, and her approach to relationships.

The track was accompanied by a music video on it’s original day of release in October 2020—then, almost exactly one year later, it appeared on the track list of Meg’s Something For Thee Hotties compilation album.

songs.full_title: Movie by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. Lil Durk)
songs.title: Movie

description.plain:
“Movie” is a strip club anthem that features Meg and Lil Durk trading braggadocios bars from two different perspectives. Meg raps from perspective of a female performer in the club, while Durk plays the role of the hypeman and brags about the benefits of being a club VIP.

It is their first collaboration.

songs.title: Tina Montana

description.plain: “Tina Montana” contains some of Megan’s hardest rhymes yet, casually threatening to take your man, snatch your wig, and clock you with a Giuseppe Zanotti heel. Cruising over warped keys and rolling hi-hats, she also lays out some history to suggest that the slick attitude runs in the family: “I had to start from the motherfuckin’ bottom/My momma told me to get ’em, I got ’em/My granny told me you goin’ to school/Getting that degree and making it cool.” Megan knows exactly when to imbue her music with that kind of specificity and personality, even in the middle of a head-nodding, trash-talking track like “Tina.” With enough tenacity, charisma, and bravado to rival that of her hometown’s most famous alumna, Megan remains unbothered. “If you don’t like it, tune the fuck out,” she raps. “And you must like it, ’cause you tuned the fuck in.”

songs.full_title: What's New by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: What’s New

description.plain: In “What’s New” Megan thee Stallion shows off a more carefree side of herself. Accompanied by a hard-hitting beat, Megan sends a message to all of her haters and boasts about her newfound success. She brushes off all negativity and delivers clever and powerful bars on this anthemic track.

songs.full_title: Circles by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Circles

description.plain:
“Circles” follows Megan spitting about relationship struggles, from trust issues to speaking about personal feelings, and says she’s gonna turn this song into a “bad bitch song” for women dealing with similar problems.

The title of “Circles” and several of its lyrics are directly inspired by “Holding You Down (Goin' in Circles)”, a 2010 track by singer Jazmine Sullivan whose instrumental is heavily sampled throughout the song.

Meg revamps the original song’s subject matter of a dysfunctional relationship and puts a less distraught spin on it, making it clear throughout the song that she’s unfazed by the shenanigans as she can always find another guy.

songs.full_title: Freaky Girls by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. SZA)
songs.title: Freaky Girls

description.plain:
“Freaky Girls” is a sexy R&B banger that features SZA and Megan Thee Stallion going back and forth trading verses about their sexual prowess. It features some classic ‘90s production by Three Six Mafia legend Juicy J, sampling Adina Howard’s 1995 hit “Freak Like Me”. It serves as Meg’s and SZA’s first collab.

In an interview with Zane Lowe on January 24, 2020 following the release of Suga’s single “B.I.T.C.H.,” Megan revealed she had an upcoming collaboration with  SZA:

I’m not gonna lie, my friend SZA, she pulled up on me in the studio because we have a song that’s gonna be on my album too and it was so fire making that song with her. Juicy J produced it, we know I love Juicy J.

songs.full_title: Running Up Freestyle by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Running Up Freestyle

description.plain: First debuted during the Fire in the Booth segment of Charlie Sloth Rap Show, “Running Up Freestyle” closes Fever. The freestyle is a perfect encapsulation of Megan’s acuity and jocular self-awareness. Over a fast-paced electronic beat from her frequent production collaborator LilJuMadeDaBeat, Megan comes for her crown and addresses both male and female spectators.

songs.full_title: Tuned In Freestyle by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Tuned In Freestyle

description.plain:
“Tuned In” is Megan Thee Stallion’s third freestyle of 2021, released only ten days after “Outta Town,” which came before it.

In quintessential Meg fashion, she calls on Juicy J and OG Parker to create an upbeat track that sets the stage for her fast and innovative verses that are full of attitude and humor.

songs.artist_names: Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. 2 Chainz & Big Sean)
songs.full_title: Go Crazy by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. 2 Chainz & Big Sean)
songs.title: Go Crazy

description.plain:
“Go Crazy” is a Bop with high volume backtalk and character. Between spitting bars about street fighting, dissing a few females, and showing the R-rated side of their lives, it was sure to be a classy hit.

While originating from a track that was only containing Megan Thee Stallion and Big Sean, 2 Chainz later jumped on it days before the official release. This caused the tracklist to change on Megan and Big Sean’s social media accounts.

Big Sean being featured was quite a shocker for fans. Since the drama between Tory Lanez and Megan thee stallion was heated, and Sean being friends with Tory, fans assumed that that would exclude Sean from ever being featured on one of Megan’s projects. Good News erased that assumption by adding it on the official album, letting it be clear that Megan was hands-on board for adding friends of Tory on her tracks.

Megan announced via Instagram live that the 2021 “Next Generation” tour was canceled because of the COVID-19 outbreak. Nevertheless, it is rescheduled for later in 2021 and Megan is performing “Go Crazy” alongside various hits in front of a live audience. On the account that Gunna is premiering the tour with Megan, he has a couple of verses on “Go Crazy” as well as vocals on other songs that were not originally featuring him.

songs.full_title: Pressurelicious by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. Future)
songs.title: Pressurelicious

description.plain:
On the third single from Megan Thee Stallion’s second studio album, “Pressurelicious,” Meg and Atlanta rap legend Future flow back to back over a simple but hard-hitting beat that features a periodic piano riff, trading braggadocious bars about their affluence, their sex lives, and their shared toxicity.

After teasing the track for a few weeks before it was officially announced, the single cover and release date was revealed just two days before the song was due to drop at midnight on July 22, 2022. However, Megan ended up putting it out three hours earlier than arranged as a result of an unfortunate leak.

SINCE IT ALREADY LEAKED LOL PRESSURELICIOUS ft. @future OUT NOWWWWWWW EVERY WHERE 🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥🔥 run it up hottiessss
— Megan Thee Stallion, via Instagram post

songs.full_title: Ain't Equal by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Ain’t Equal

description.plain: “Ain’t Equal” is a song of triumph and overcoming obstacles. Houston bred rapper, Megan addresses the “haters” lets them know she fears no one and will continue to reign and be unstoppable in the game. It had been a devastating and tumultuous year; Meg lost her great-grandmother in the third month of 2019, two weeks later, in the same month, her mother/manager and mentor, Holly Thomas, tragically lost her battle with stage four brain cancer. Having suffered in recent years negative reviews and responses from critics and naysayers who believed she was a passing short scene-stealer and one-hit wonder with her sexy image labeling her overly-sexualized, explicit and “exploitive” and her lyrics too raunchy, a prominent fixture in the hip-hop mainstream. What many would regard as further reinscribing the media’s depictions of Jezebel/Sapphire trope of Black women’s sexuality and representation. The self-proclaimed braggadocios “Hot Girl” Meg’s response to the negative Nancy’s is that they “aren’t equal” and not on her level and she’s gonna do her, regardless of others views, interest and efforts to “contain” her.

songs.full_title: Fire In The Booth (Pt. 1) by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Fire In The Booth (Pt. 1)

description.plain: During a March installment of the Charlie Sloth Rap Show’s Fire in the Booth segment, Megan The Stallion ended the show providing two freestyles. The first debuted freestyle, “Running Up Freestyle,” appears as the last track on her 2019 project, Fever. Both freestyles are a perfect encapsulation of Megan’s acuity and jocular self-awareness. Over a fast-paced electronic beat from her frequent production collaborator LilJuMadeDaBeat, Megan comes for her crown and addresses both male and female spectators.

songs.full_title: Stallion Houston Cypher Verse by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Stallion Houston Cypher Verse

description.plain:
The Houston Cypher is a project put together by Merrick Needham also known as “Zion’s view”.

The Cypher features artists from all around Houston, with different backgrounds and different musical styles. This quality makes it a perfect opportunity to showcase the talent the city has.

In 2016, Megan Thee Stallion appeared on the first ever Houston Cypher, which is where this verse comes from.
https://youtu.be/_gCBwtwYyZg?t=92

songs.full_title: Her by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Her

description.plain: ‘Her’ is the fifth track on Megan’s Album ‘Traumazine’. The track overflows with boastfulness. The track was released on the 12th of August 2022,with a majority of the other tracks on the album. It later received an Official Music Video three days later. This shot up the popularity of the track such that it debuted at #62 on the Billboard Hot 100 during the chart week ending of August 27, 2022.

songs.title: Hit My Phone

description.plain: “Hit My Phone” is the fourth track on Megan Thee Stallion’s third EP Suga. The song features an aggressive background beat and vocals from Californian R&B singer Kehlani. On the track, the two speak about sending “risky texts” and getting drunk to secure a relationship.

songs.full_title: Outside by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Outside

description.plain:
On “Outside” Megan brushes off what people say to  or about her and simply keeps it real with everyone that she’ll do whatever she wants.

She discusses her past relationship stating what he did for her and if he didn’t like the way she carries herself he shouldn’t have dealt with her. She continues and slightly exposes how in love he was with her and her personalities. Then finally dissing her ex and his new girl and boasts that anyone one after her is a downgrade.

songs.full_title: Hood Rat Shit by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Hood Rat Shit

description.plain:
Sampling a viral news clip from 2008, Megan Thee Stallion channels bad behaviour energy and makes references to South Park and Wakanda on “Hood Rat Shit.” The song is featured as the second track from her debut mixtape Fever.

Featuring production from Koncept P (6ix9ine, Fredo Bang) & KC Supreme (Trevor Daniels, YK Osiris), the track brushes across numerous classic Megan themes – having a good time and her love for money.

songs.full_title: Anxiety by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Anxiety

description.plain:
“Anxiety” acknowledges Megan’s gracious disclosures about what she goes through during stressful times, while also revealing her grief over her mother’s loss. The song has a strong humanistic feel to it, aided by loopy pianos and a wailing vocal sample.

Megan explained in an Apple Music interview that the song felt like she was largely talking about her mother and that she composed it to get it off her chest.

songs.full_title: Intercourse by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. Mustard & Popcaan)
songs.title: Intercourse

description.plain:
On “Intercouse” Megan Thee Stallion teams up with dancehall legend Popcaan and west coast producer Mustard for a tropical flavored banger about the song’s title.  On the track Meg and Popcaan trade verses about how prepared and eager they are to get to the main event.

The track is Megan’s first collaboration with  Popcaan, and her second with Mustard who she previously collaborated with on “Y U Mad” off Wiz Khalifa’s album.

songs.full_title: Ungrateful by Megan Thee Stallion (Ft. Key Glock)
songs.title: Ungrateful

description.plain:
“Ungrateful” is the second track from Megan The Stallions 2022 album Traumazine, the first song on the album with a feature and guest’s Memphis' rapper Key Glock.

Meg & Glock narrate “Ungrateful” with a dramatic dialog on thanklessness, under a brooding piano led-trap beat courtesy of BandPlay. The song matches it’s early album counterparts on Traumazine, sharing speedy flows, angry and cocky bars, with darker and colder instrumentation.

But the real moral of “Ungrateful” is that when Megan cuts you out of her life, you’re done with no second chance, muse or not.

songs.full_title: Don’t Rock Me to Sleep by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Don’t Rock Me to Sleep

description.plain: “Don’t Rock Me to Sleep” is a synth-pop ballad featuring less of Megan’s rapping skills and delves more into her singing. The song is about how relationships should have good communication, and people in them shouldn’t be told the truth lightly and instead be giving it honestly and out front.

songs.full_title: Southside Forever Freestyle by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Southside Forever Freestyle

description.plain:
“Southside Forever” is Megan Thee Stallion’s first freestyle of 2021, released the same day as her 26th birthday on February 15.

Teaming up with friends and frequent collaborators Lil Ju and Juicy J for the punchy instrumental, Meg delivers lyrics about her superstar lifestyle and the haters that come with it.

“Bless The Booth Freestyle” is one of two freestyles on the “Something for Thee Hotties” album. It was shot for Tidal’s “Bless The Booth” series in June 2019 and initially a Tidal exclusive before being included in Megan’s 2021 album.

songs.full_title: Outta Town Freestyle by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Outta Town Freestyle

description.plain:
“Outta Town” is Megan Thee Stallion’s second freestyle released in 2021, following five months after “Southside Forever.”

Flowing over another trusty beat made by Lil Ju, Meg raps a singular verse that addresses naysayers and showcases her lyrical creativity.

songs.full_title: Bae Goals by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Bae Goals

description.plain:
“Bae Goals” sees Megan Thee Stallion describe her perfect partner and name-drop three famous power couples: Kim Kardashian and Kanye West (KimYe), Keyshia Cole and Gucci Mane, and Jay-Z and Beyoncé.







Interestingly, this track raises questions about when it was recorded given the demise of KimYe’s marriage with Kim Kardashian officially filing for divorce in February 2021, despite the song being released in October 2021.
Source: Cosmopolitan, Varsity

songs.full_title: God's Favorite by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: God’s Favorite

description.plain:
As the aptly-named title suggests, on track 13 of Something For Thee Hotties: Megan discusses feeling blessed and highly favored, as well as the abundance of desirable qualities she possesses—being beautiful, successful, wealthy, etc.

Interestingly, in a promotional video posted to her Instagram a few months before the song’s release, Megan was seen wearing a t-shirt that reads ‘GOD’S FAVORITE’.

description.plain: This is the 9th song on Megan thee Stallion’s album “Something For Thee Hotties”. In this song, she talks about how she wants to get all of a man’s money by any means necessary even if they are illegal.  She also talks about how she wants to date a man whose net worth can match hers in the first verse.

songs.full_title: Pipe Up by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Pipe Up

description.plain: Pitchfork characterized the upbeat “Pipe Up” as having “the buzzy energy of a marathon studio session.” In the track, Megan tells her partner to speak up if he wants to have sex with her. She also defends herself from insinuations that she’s a gold digger and responds that she is a self-made woman, branding herself Money Makin' Megan.

description.plain: This is Megan Thee Stallions XXL Freestyle for the class of 2019. She has been making a name for herself for a little over a year and earned her spot on the highly prestigious XXL class along other stars like Dababy, Roddy Ricch, Gunna, and others. She is known for her freestyling abilities so it is not a surprise she would show up ready for hers.

songs.full_title: Why I Speak Up for Black Women by Megan Thee Stallion
songs.title: Why I Speak Up for Black Women
songs.title_with_featured: Why I Speak Up for Black Women

description.plain:
This spoken work piece provides the narration for the video supplement to Megan Thee Stallion’s New York Times Op-Ed piece, in which she addresses competition between Black women in hip hop, relates how she has been the victim of violence, reflects on the Black female experience and asserts that her use of the phrase “Protect Black Women” in an October 3rd Saturday Night Live performance of her song “Savage” “should not be controversial.”

The video includes samples of a 1962 speech by iconic yet controversial civil rights leader Malcolm X that were also heard during her SNL performance.

This spoken work piece provides the narration for the video supplement to Megan Thee Stallion’s New York Times Op-Ed piece, in which she addresses competition between Black women in hip hop, relates how she has been the victim of violence, reflects on the Black female experience and asserts that her use of the phrase “Protect Black Women” in an October 3rd Saturday Night Live performance of her song “Savage” “should not be controversial.”

The video includes samples of a 1962 speech by iconic yet controversial civil rights leader Malcolm X that were also heard during her SNL performance.

songs.lyrics:

What does it mean to be a woman of color?
She's gotta be strong, because that's just the expectation
Loving herself, but not too much

Being his lady in the streets, but his freak in the sheets
Inheriting her grandma's love, but always loving the wrong one
Twerking for her man, but not with her friends?
Being constantly told she's "too much," or, "not enough"

[Malcolm X]
The most disrespected person is the Black Woman
[Megan Thee Stallion]
Constantly having to prove she's a victim because society sides with a man
Not being able to express her traumas because she can't show no weakness
Is constantly told that she's too dark, too thin, too thick
Too much of a bitch
Being murdered, beaten, abused
Then questioned if she evoked all of it
Is left out on the street to become the flower that grows from the concrete

[Malcolm X]
Who taught you to hate yourself, from the top of your head, to the soles of your feet?

[Megan Thee Stallion]
She marches for everyone else
Riots for everyone else
Dies for everyone else
She loves everyone else
Lives for everyone else
But when it comes down to her, it ain't a mothafucka in sight

The system as a whole has failed her

If you've never been shot, you don't know her pain

Say her name
Eighteen women of color murdered3Embed
